_decoded_content.name: Accessibility Gaming Mouse
_decoded_content.description: A little over a year ago on YouTube I posted a video on how to make a DIY game controller from scratch with arduino. The video has done very well and opened up some unique opportunities for me including working with my local library to build controllers with kids to teach about electronics and coding. Recently I was emailed by a viewer who explained that he is unable to use his right hand due to a stroke. He expressed interest in developing a one-handed mouse system such that one could control WASD and other buttons in addition to normal mouse actions. I quickly began working during quarantine to develop this controller. Very simply it uses an arduino pro micro board, a joystick, and a few buttons to act as a usb game controller. With https://joytokey.net/en/ software the control inputs are mapped to specific keys. To create the code for this project one must download the arduino joystick library by Matthew Heironimus at https://github.com/MHeironimus/ArduinoJoystickLibrary. Originally the base of the controller had a thin platform on which the mouse rested. However, I found that some mice needed to make full contact with the table surface to function properly. As a result, I created a base version without this thin raised platform. If your mouse only works when making full contact with your mouse pad or desk, use this bottomless version. If you are interested in this project please watch my tutorial video on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gHSD-KqGbn0&t=10s&ab_channel=Benjijart

The video has done very well and opened up some unique opportunities for me including working with my local library to build controllers with kids to teach about electronics and coding. Recently I was emailed by a viewer who explained that he is unable to use his right hand due to a stroke. He expressed interest in developing a one-handed mouse system such that one could control WASD and other buttons in addition to normal mouse actions. I quickly began working during quarantine to develop this controller. Very simply it uses an arduino pro micro board, a joystick, and a few buttons to act as a usb game controller. With https://joytokey.net/en/ software the control inputs are mapped to specific keys. To create the code for this project one must download the arduino joystick library by Matthew Heironimus at https://github.com/MHeironimus/ArduinoJoystickLibrary. Originally the base of the controller had a thin platform on which the mouse rested. However, I found that some mice needed to make full contact with the table surface to function properly. As a result, I created a base version without this thin raised platform. If your mouse only works when making full contact with your mouse pad or desk, use this bottomless version. If you are interested in this project please watch my tutorial video on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gHSD-KqGbn0&t=10s&ab_channel=Benjijart
_decoded_content.details:
Summary

A little over a year ago on YouTube I posted a video on how to make a DIY game controller from scratch with arduino. The video has done very well and opened up some unique opportunities for me including working with my local library to build controllers with kids to teach about electronics and coding. Recently I was emailed by a viewer who explained that he is unable to use his right hand due to a stroke. He expressed interest in developing a one-handed mouse system such that one could control WASD and other buttons in addition to normal mouse actions. I quickly began working during quarantine to develop this controller. Very simply it uses an arduino pro micro board, a joystick, and a few buttons to act as a usb game controller. With https://joytokey.net/en/ software the control inputs are mapped to specific keys. To create the code for this project one must download the arduino joystick library by Matthew Heironimus at https://github.com/MHeironimus/ArduinoJoystickLibrary. Originally the base of the controller had a thin platform on which the mouse rested. However, I found that some mice needed to make full contact with the table surface to function properly. As a result, I created a base version without this thin raised platform. If your mouse only works when making full contact with your mouse pad or desk, use this bottomless version. If you are interested in this project please watch my tutorial video on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gHSD-KqGbn0&t=10s&ab_channel=Benjijart

Custom Section

Arduino Code

            <div><p>(#)include //includes the joystick library by Matthew Heironimus<br>\\get rid of the parentheses around the hashtag above thingiverse was just being weird<br>Joystick_ Joystick;//creates the joystick</p><p>int xaxis = 0; //creates axis values<br>int yaxis = 0;</p><p>const bool initAutoSendState = true; </p><p>void setup() {<br>Joystick.begin(); //starts joystick<br>pinMode(9,INPUT_PULLUP); //sets up our buttons<br>pinMode(8,INPUT_PULLUP);<br>pinMode(7,INPUT_PULLUP);<br>}</p><p>void loop() {<br>// put your main code here, to run repeatedly:<br>xaxis = analogRead(A1); //sets xaxis value equal to the analog input from the real stick<br>xaxis = map(xaxis,0,1023,0,255); //maps xaxis from 0-1023 to new range of 0-255<br>Joystick.setXAxis(xaxis); //links our xaxis value to the xaxis of the virtual joystick created by the mheironimus library</p><p>yaxis = analogRead(A0);<br>yaxis = map(yaxis,0,1023,255,0);<br>Joystick.setYAxis(yaxis);</p><p>if (digitalRead(9)== LOW) //if the button connected to pin 9 is pressed<br>{Joystick.pressButton(0);} //button 0 is pressed<br>else<br>{Joystick.releaseButton(0);} //otherwise button 0 is not pressed</p><p>if (digitalRead(8)== LOW)<br>{Joystick.pressButton(1);}<br>else<br>{Joystick.releaseButton(1);} </p><p>if (digitalRead(7)== LOW)<br>{Joystick.pressButton(2);}<br>else<br>{Joystick.releaseButton(2);}<br>}</p></div>

data.content: A little over a year ago on YouTube I posted a video on how to make a DIY game controller from scratch with arduino. The video has done very well and opened up some unique opportunities for me including working with my local library to build controllers with kids to teach about electronics and coding. Recently I was emailed by a viewer who explained that he is unable to use his right hand due to a stroke. He expressed interest in developing a one-handed mouse system such that one could control WASD and other buttons in addition to normal mouse actions. I quickly began working during quarantine to develop this controller. Very simply it uses an arduino pro micro board, a joystick, and a few buttons to act as a usb game controller. With https://joytokey.net/en/ software the control inputs are mapped to specific keys. To create the code for this project one must download the arduino joystick library by Matthew Heironimus at https://github.com/MHeironimus/ArduinoJoystickLibrary. Originally the base of the controller had a thin platform on which the mouse rested. However, I found that some mice needed to make full contact with the table surface to function properly. As a result, I created a base version without this thin raised platform. If your mouse only works when making full contact with your mouse pad or desk, use this bottomless version. If you are interested in this project please watch my tutorial video on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gHSD-KqGbn0&t=10s&ab_channel=Benjijart

data.title: Arduino Code
data.content:
(#)include //includes the joystick library by Matthew Heironimus
\\get rid of the parentheses around the hashtag above thingiverse was just being weird
Joystick_ Joystick;//creates the joystick

int xaxis = 0; //creates axis values
int yaxis = 0;

const bool initAutoSendState = true;

void setup() {
Joystick.begin(); //starts joystick
pinMode(9,INPUT_PULLUP); //sets up our buttons
pinMode(8,INPUT_PULLUP);
pinMode(7,INPUT_PULLUP);
}

void loop() {
// put your main code here, to run repeatedly:
xaxis = analogRead(A1); //sets xaxis value equal to the analog input from the real stick
xaxis = map(xaxis,0,1023,0,255); //maps xaxis from 0-1023 to new range of 0-255
Joystick.setXAxis(xaxis); //links our xaxis value to the xaxis of the virtual joystick created by the mheironimus library

yaxis = analogRead(A0);
yaxis = map(yaxis,0,1023,255,0);
Joystick.setYAxis(yaxis);

if (digitalRead(9)== LOW) //if the button connected to pin 9 is pressed
{Joystick.pressButton(0);} //button 0 is pressed
else
{Joystick.releaseButton(0);} //otherwise button 0 is not pressed

if (digitalRead(8)== LOW)
{Joystick.pressButton(1);}
else
{Joystick.releaseButton(1);}

if (digitalRead(7)== LOW)
{Joystick.pressButton(2);}
else
{Joystick.releaseButton(2);}
}
